{{Coord|46.220787|6.143574|region:CH-GE_type:landmark|display=title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use British English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox |name = Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces |bodystyle = |title = Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces |titlestyle = |image = [[File:DCAF Logo English.jpg|250px]] |size = |imagestyle = |caption = |captionstyle = |headerstyle = background:#ccf; |labelstyle = background:#ddf; |datastyle = |label5 = Founded |data5 = {{Start date and age|October 2000}} |label6 = Type |data6 = [[Foundation (nonprofit)|Foundation]]-based [[international development]] [[think tank]] |label7 = Headquarters |data7 = Chemin Eugène-Rigot 2E
[[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]] |label8 = Offices |data8 = [[Beirut]], [[Brussels]], [[Ljubljana]], [[Ramallah]], [[Tunis]] |label9 = Member States |data9 = 62 states and the [[Canton of Geneva]] (2016) |label10 = Permanent Observers |data10 = 4 governments, 2 international organisations (2016) |label11 = Director |data11 = Ambassador Thomas Guerber |label12 = Staff |data12 = 171 (2016) |label13 = Web Address |data13 = {{URL|http://dcaf.ch/}} |label14=Budget|data14=24 million CHF (2016)|image2=[[File:DCAF HQ outside.jpg|250px]]|caption2=Entrance to DCAF headquarters at Petal 5, [[Maison de la Paix]], [[Geneva]]}} '''DCAF''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|d|i|ˌ|k|æ|f}}; '''Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces'''; [[French language|French]]: ''Centre pour le contrôle démocratique des forces armées - Genève,'' [[German language|German]]: ''Genfer Zentrum für die demokratische Kontrolle der Streitkräfte'') is an intergovernmental [[Foundation (nonprofit)|foundation]]-based [[think tank]] that provides research and project support to states and international actors in improving [[security sector governance and reform]] (SSG and SSR). DCAF was established in 2000 in the [[Canton of Geneva]] by the [[Switzerland|Swiss government]] and as of 2018 employs around 170 staff, has seven permanent offices and 63 member states. == Mandate == DCAF was established in October 2000 under [[Law of Switzerland|Swiss law]] as a foundation and on the initiative of the [[Switzerland|Swiss government]].{{Cite book|url=|title=DCAF By-Laws (unofficial translation from French)|last=|first=|publisher=|year=2000|isbn=|location=Geneva|pages=}} The organization states that it is a [[good governance]]-promoting foundation focusing on a specific [[public sector]] area—the [[National security|security sector]]. DCAF is mandated by its intergovernmental Foundation Council to assist partner states and international actors in improving the governance of the security sector through [[reform]] based on international norms and good practices.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gpplatform.ch/pbguide/organisation/geneva-centre-democratic-control-armed-forces-dcaf|title=Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces (DCAF) {{!}} GPPlatform|website=www.gpplatform.ch|access-date=2017-05-28|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170824012946/http://www.gpplatform.ch/pbguide/organisation/geneva-centre-democratic-control-armed-forces-dcaf|archivedate=24 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} == Activities == DCAF states that it provides in‐country advisory support and practical assistance programmes, identifies recommendations and good practices, develops and promotes norms and standards, and conducts tailored policy research.{{Cite web|url=http://studylib.net/doc/14926431/dcaf-strategy-2016-%E2%80%93-2019-dcaf-at-a-glance-adopted-by-dca...|title=DCAF Strategy 2016 – 2019|last=|first=|date=2015-06-09|website=Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces (DCAF)|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170918202542/http://studylib.net/doc/14926431/dcaf-strategy-2016-%E2%80%93-2019-dcaf-at-a-glance-adopted-by-dca...|archive-date=18 September 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=|df=dmy-all}} In 2017, DCAF supported national and international partners in more than 70 countries. The think tank reports that it collaborates with international organizations, such as the [[United Nations]], [[NATO]], the [[African Union]], the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]] (OSCE) and the [[European Union]] (EU).{{Cite web|url=http://unog.ch/80256EE600583A0B/(httpPages)/C002F756C3E83A03C1257E3B004A21AA?OpenDocument|title=UNOG - DCAF Seminars|last=|first=|date=|website=unog.ch|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170702093438/http://www.unog.ch/80256EE600583A0B/(httpPages)/C002F756C3E83A03C1257E3B004A21AA?OpenDocument|archive-date=2 July 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=2017-05-28|df=dmy-all}} DCAF was ranked the 33rd (out of 65) in the Top Transparency and Good Governance Think Tanks and the 35th (out of 104) in the Top Defense and National Security Think Tanks on the 2017 [https://repository.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1012&context=think_tanks Global Go To Think Tank Index] The foundation is one of only seven institutions worldwide represented in both categories.{{Cite book|url=http://repository.upenn.edu/think_tanks/12|title=2016 Global Go To Think Tank Index Report|last=McGann|first=James|publisher=University of Pennsylvania|year=2017|isbn=|series=TTCSP Global Go To Think Tank Index Reports. 12.|location=|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170606205428/http://repository.upenn.edu/think_tanks/12/|archivedate=6 June 2017|df=dmy-all}} Likewise, an external evaluation published in 2014 assessed that DCAF 'has an excellent reputation as an organization with solid expertise'.{{Cite book|url=https://www.aramis.admin.ch/Default.aspx?DocumentID=3782&Load=true|title=External Evaluation of the Geneva Centres, GCSP, GICHD and DCAF (2010-2013)|last=|first=|publisher=INNOVABRIDGE Foundation|year=2014|isbn=|location=Caslano|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180302163539/https://www.aramis.admin.ch/Default.aspx?DocumentID=3782&Load=true|archivedate=2 March 2018|df=dmy-all}} == Infrastructure, staff and budget == DCAF headquarters is located at the [[Maison de la paix|Maison de la Paix]] complex in [[Geneva]] together with its 'sister centres', the [[Geneva International Centre for Humanitarian Demining]] (GICHD) and the [[Geneva Centre for Security Policy]] (GCSP), as well as the [[Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies|Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies (IHEID)]] and other [[peacebuilding]]-related institutions.{{Cite web|url=http://www.finlandmission.ch/public/default.aspx?nodeid=35482&contentlan=2&culture=en-US|title=Disarmament and arms control|last=|first=|date=|website=Permanent Mission of Finland, Geneva|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107010344/http://www.finlandmission.ch/public/default.aspx?nodeid=35482&contentlan=2&culture=en-US|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=2017-11-03|df=dmy-all}} In January 2018, DCAF became a member of the [http://gpplatform.ch/ Geneva Peacebuilding Platform] (GPP), a 'a knowledge hub that connects the critical mass of peacebuilding actors, resources, and expertise in Geneva and worldwide'. DCAF also maintains permanent offices in [[Beirut]], [[Brussels]], [[Ljubljana]], [[Ramallah]], [[Tripoli]], and [[Tunis]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.eda.admin.ch/eda/en/home/foreign-policy/human-rights/peace/maison-paix.html|title=Geneva Centres «Maison de la Paix»|last=|first=|date=2016-11-30|website=Swiss Federal Department of Foreign Affairs|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170824005925/https://www.eda.admin.ch/eda/en/home/foreign-policy/human-rights/peace/maison-paix.html|archive-date=24 August 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=2017-05-28|df=dmy-all}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.maisondelapaix.ch/en/|title=Maison de la Paix|website=www.maisondelapaix.ch|access-date=2017-05-28|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170606143041/http://www.maisondelapaix.ch/en/|archivedate=6 June 2017|df=dmy-all}} In 2017, DCAF employed 170 staff, of whom 60% were women, from 40 different nationalities. Its budget was 29 million [[Swiss franc|Swiss francs]]. Switzerland provided approximately 66% of the budget and DCAF's top donors in descending order are currently: Switzerland, Germany, Netherlands, United Kingdom, Sweden, Denmark, Norway, European Union, Luxembourg, Ireland. All funding to DCAF qualifies as [[official development assistance]].{{Cite book|url=http://www.dcaf.ch/annual-reports|title=Promoting Good Governance of the Security Sector - DCAF Annual Report 2016|last=|first=|publisher=Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces (DCAF)|year=2017|isbn=92-9222-437-9|location=Geneva|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170915023609/http://www.dcaf.ch/annual-reports|archivedate=15 September 2017|df=dmy-all}} == Organization == The Foundation Council is DCAF’s supreme decision-making body. As of 2016 it comprises 62 states and the [[Canton of Geneva]] as well as four governments and two international organizations that hold observer status. DCAF is organized as a think-and-do tank and at the headquarters its work is carried out according to four pillars:{{Cite web|url=http://www.dcaf.ch/organisational-structure|title=Organisational Structure {{!}} DCAF a center for security, development and the rule of law|last=|first=|date=|website=www.dcaf.ch|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170915023236/http://www.dcaf.ch/organisational-structure|archive-date=15 September 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=2017-09-14|df=dmy-all}} {{div col}} * {{em|Policy & Research Department}} ** Policy & Research Division ** Gender & Security Division ** Public-Private Partnerships {{Infobox software | name = Database of Macromolecular Motions | released = {{Start date and age|1996}} | author = [[Mark Bender Gerstein|Mark B. Gerstein]]
[[Werner G. Krebs]] | developer = molmovdb.org team at [[Yale University]] | status = Active{{cite web|url=http://www.molmovdb.org|title=Database of Macromolecular Motions Website}} | genre = [[bioinformatics]] [[database]], [[Software as a service]] | website ={{URL|molmovdb.org}} }} The '''Database of Macromolecular Motions''' [http://www.molmovdb.org (molmovdb)] is a [[bioinformatics]] [[database]] and [[Software as a service|software-as-a-service]] tool that attempts to categorize [[macromolecular]] motions, sometimes also known as [[conformational change]].{{Cite journal|title = Hot Picks|url = http://www.sciencemag.org/content/284/5416/871.2|journal = Science|date = 1999-05-07|issn = 0036-8075|pages = 871–871|volume = 284|issue = 5416|doi = 10.1126/science.284.5416.871b|language = en}}{{cite book |title= Structural Bioinformatics |veditors=Bourne PE, Helge W | year=2003 |location= Hoboken, NJ | publisher=Wiley-Liss | isbn= 978-0-471-20199-1 |oclc= 50199108|page=229}}{{cite journal |author1=Bourne,PE |author2=Murray-Rust, J |author3=Lakey JH |title=Protein-nucleic acid interactions Folding and binding Web alert |journal=Current Opinion in Structural Biology |volume=9 |issue= 1|pages=9–10 |date=Feb 1999|doi=10.1016/S0959-440X(99)90000-3}} It was originally developed by [[Mark Bender Gerstein|Mark B. Gerstein]], [[Werner G. Krebs|Werner Krebs]], and Nat Echols in the Molecular Biophysics & Biochemistry Department at [[Yale University]].{{cite web|title=Morphs|url=http://proteopedia.org/wiki/index.php/Morphs|website=Proteopeida|publisher= Proteopeida|accessdate=2015-10-30}}{{cite report|editor-last1=Borner|title = Knowledge Management and Visualization Tools in Support of Discovery (NSF Workshop Report)|publisher=National Science Foundation Workshop|page=5|url=http://vw.slis.indiana.edu/cdi2008/NSF-Report.pdf}} == Discussion == Since its introduction in the late 1990s, peer-reviewed papers on the database have received thousands of citations.{{Cite web|title = Mark Gerstein - Google Scholar Citations|url = https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=YvjuUugAAAAJ|website = scholar.google.com|accessdate = 2015-12-26}}{{Cite web|title = Werner G. Krebs - Google Scholar Citations|url = https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=zVjmhJ8AAAAJ&hl=en|website = scholar.google.com|accessdate = 2015-12-26}} The database has been mentioned in news articles in major scientific journals, book chapters, and elsewhere. Users can search the database for a particular motion by either [[protein]] name or [[Protein Data Bank]] ID number.{{cite journal |vauthors=Gerstein M, Krebs W |title=A database of macromolecular motions |journal=Nucleic Acids Res. |volume=26 |issue=18 |pages=4280–90 |date=September 1998 |pmid= 9722650|pmc=147832 |url=http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=9722650 |doi=10.1093/nar/26.18.4280}} Typically, however, users will enter the database via the [[Protein Data Bank]], which often provides a hyperlink to the molmovdb entry for proteins found in both databases. The database includes a web-based tool (the Morph server) which allows non-experts to animate and visualize certain types of protein [[conformational change]] through the generation of short movies. This system uses [[molecular modelling]] techniques to [[interpolate]] the structural changes between two different protein conformers and to generate a set of intermediate structures. A hyperlink pointing to the morph results is then emailed to the user.{{cite journal |vauthors=Krebs WG, Gerstein M |title=SURVEY AND SUMMARY: The morph server: a standardized system for analyzing and visualizing macromolecular motions in a database framework |journal=Nucleic Acids Res. |volume=28 |issue=8 |pages=1665–75 |date=April 2000 |pmid=10734184 |pmc=102811 |url=http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=10734184 |doi=10.1093/nar/28.8.1665}} The Morph Server was originally primarily a research tool rather than general molecular animation tool, and thus offered only limited user control over rendering, animation parameters, color, and point of view, and the original methods sometimes required a fair amount of CPU time to completion.{{cite journal |vauthors=Maiti R, Van Domselaar GH, Wishart DS |title=MovieMaker: a web server for rapid rendering of protein motions and interactions |journal=Nucleic Acids Res. |volume=33 |issue=Web Server issue |pages=W358–62 |date=July 2005 |pmid=15980488 |pmc=1160245 |doi=10.1093/nar/gki485 }} Since their initial introduction in 1996, the database and associated morph server have undergone development to try to address some of these shortcomings{{cite journal|pmid=16381870|pmc=1347409|title=The Database of Macromolecular Motions: new features added at the decade mark|journal=Nucleic Acids Research|volume=34|issue=Database issue|pages=D296–301|year=2006|author1=Flores|first1=S|last2=Echols|first2=N|last3=Milburn|first3=D|last4=Hespenheide|first4=B|last5=Keating|first5=K|last6=Lu|first6=J|last7=Wells|first7=S|last8=Yu|first8=E. Z.|last9=Thorpe|first9=M|last10=Gerstein|first10=M|doi=10.1093/nar/gkj046}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Alexandrov V, Gerstein M |title=Using 3D Hidden Markov Models that explicitly represent spatial coordinates to model and compare protein structures |journal=BMC Bioinformatics |volume=5|pages=2 |date=January 2004 |pmid=14715091 |pmc=344530 |doi=10.1186/1471-2105-5-2 }} as well as add new features, such as [[Normal Mode]] Analysis.{{cite journal |vauthors=Alexandrov V, Lehnert U, Echols N, Milburn D, Engelman D, Gerstein M |title=Normal modes for predicting protein motions: A comprehensive database assessment and associated Web tool |journal=Protein Sci. |volume=14 |issue=3 |pages=633–43 |date=March 2005 |pmid=15722444 |pmc=2279292 |doi=10.1110/ps.04882105 }} Other research grounds have subsequently developed alternative systems, such as [http://wishart.biology.ualberta.ca/moviemaker MovieMaker] from the [[University of Alberta]]. == Commercialization == Bioinformatics vendor [[DNASTAR]] has incorporated morphs from the database into its commercial Protean3D product.{{Cite web|title = The Motion Library in Protean3D documentation|url = https://www.dnastar.com/protean3d_help/index.html#!Documents/themotionlibrary.htm|website = www.dnastar.com|accessdate = 2015-11-13}}{{Cite web|title = Protean3D overview|url = https://www.dnastar.com/protean3d_help/index.html#!Documents/protean3doverview.htm|website = www.dnastar.com|accessdate = 2015-11-13}} The connection between DNASTAR and the authors of the database, if any, is not immediately clear. ==See also== *[[Database of protein conformational diversity]] ==Notes== *{{cite book| last= Gu| first= Jenny| last2 = Bourne| first2 = Philip E.| title= Structural Bioinformatics|edition= 2nd | publisher= Wiley-Blackwell|date=March 2009| isbn= 0-470-18105-2}} *{{cite book|isbn=1441910433|chapter=Chapter 26 on Protein Motions|title=The Physics of Proteins: An Introduction to Biological Physics and Molecular Biophysics (Biological and Medical Physics, Biomedical Engineering)}} *{{cite journal |author=Frauenfelder H |title=New looks at protein motions |journal=Nature |volume=338 |issue= 6217|pages=623–4 |date=20 April 1989 |doi=10.1038/338623a0 |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v338/n6217/abs/338623a0.html}} *{{cite journal |vauthors=Alexandrov V, Lehnert U, Echols N, Milburn D, Engelman D, Gerstein M |title=Normal modes for predicting protein motions: A comprehensive database assessment and associated Web tool |journal=Protein Sci. |volume=14 |issue=3 |pages=633–43 |date=March 2005 |pmid=15722444 |pmc=2279292 |doi=10.1110/ps.04882105 }} *{{cite journal |vauthors=Alexandrov V, Gerstein M |title=Using 3D Hidden Markov Models that explicitly represent spatial coordinates to model and compare protein structures |journal=BMC Bioinformatics |volume=5|pages=2 |date=January 2004 |pmid=14715091 |pmc=344530 |doi=10.1186/1471-2105-5-2 }} *{{cite journal |vauthors=Echols N, Milburn D, Gerstein M |title=MolMovDB: analysis and visualization of conformational change and structural flexibility |journal=Nucleic Acids Res. |volume=31 |issue=1 |pages=478–82 |date=January 2003 |pmid=12520056 |pmc=165551 |url=http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=12520056 |doi=10.1093/nar/gkg104}} *{{cite journal |vauthors=Krebs WG, Alexandrov V, Wilson CA, Echols N, Yu H, Gerstein M |title=Normal mode analysis of macromolecular motions in a database framework: developing mode concentration as a useful classifying statistic |journal=Proteins |volume=48 |issue=4 |pages=682–95 |date=September 2002 |pmid=12211036 |doi=10.1002/prot.10168 }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox university | name = Deccan College Post-Graduate & Research Institute | image = <!-- Commented out: [[File:Deccan College.jpg]] --> | motto = | established = 6 October 1821 | type = [[Public university|public]] [[Deemed University]] | head = Dr. Vasant Shinde | head_label = Vice-Chancellor | city = [[Pune]] | state = [[Maharashtra]] | country = [[India]] | website = {{URL| www.deccancollegepune.ac.in}} }}
'''Deccan College Post-Graduate and Research Institute''' also referred to as '''Deccan College''' is a post-graduate institute of [[Archeology]], [[Linguistics]] and [[Sanskrit]] & [[Lexicography]] [[Pune]], [[India]].
==History== ===Early years (1821 to 1939)=== Established on 6 October 1821 as Hindoo College, it is one of the oldest institutions of modern learning in India. It was started under [[Mountstuart Elphinstone]] (Lt. Governor of [[Bombay Presidency]]), with funds diverted from the erstwhile Peshwa's Dakshina Fund, later disbursed by Sardar Khanderao Dabhade after the Territories of the [[Peshwa]] were annexed in 1818.<ref>[http://www.deccancollegepune.ac.in/ Deccan College website]</ref> It was also known as the Poona Sanskrit College. The first principal was Major [[Thomas Candy]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Frazer|first1=James Nelson|title=Deccan College: a retrospect, 1851-1901|date=1902|publisher=The Author|location=Poona|page=5}}</ref>
In 1837, English and other modern subjects were added to the curriculum.<ref>R.N. Dandekar, "Ramakrishna Gopal Bhandarkar and the Academic Renaissance in Maharashtra" in ''Annals of the Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute'', Vol. 69, No. 1/4 (1988), pp. 283-294.</ref> An English school was added to the college in 1842; on 7 June 1851 the English school was merged with the Hindoo College to form [[Poona College]]. In 1857, the principal was Sir [[Edwin Arnold]], followed by W.A. Russell in 1860.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Frazer|first1=James Nelson|title=Deccan College: a retrospect, 1851-1901|date=1902|publisher=The Author|location=Poona|page=6}}</ref>
From its original location in [[Vishrambaug Wada]] and later in [[Wanwadi]], the Poona College was shifted to its present large campus near Yerwada. The land was donated by the Bombay government. The foundation stone of the main building was laid on 15 October 1864. A [[Gothic Revival architecture|Victorian neo-Gothic]] building was constructed by Sir [[Henry Bartle Frere]] with a munificent 1,00,000 rupees from [[Sir Jamsetjee Jejeebhoy, 2nd Baronet]], between [[Kirkee]] and [[Yerwada]].
The college started functioning on the new campus on 23 March 1868. At this stage it was renamed as Deccan College in recognition of the enrollment of students from the entire [[Deccan Plateau|Deccan]] region. Until 1881, Deccan College was staffed by four professors, one acting as principal. Another of the four, the professor of Oriental languages, supervised five traditional Sanskrit [[shastri]]s and an expert in Zend [[Pahlevi]] in an extensive program of research and text publication, in addition to his teaching duties.<ref>Ellen E. McDonald, "English Education and Social Reform in Late Nineteenth Century Bombay: A Case Study in the Transmission of a Cultural Ideal" in ''The Journal of Asian Studies'', Vol. 25, No. 3 (May, 1966), pp. 453-470.</ref> Student enrollment rose to a peak of 210 in 1885. William Wordsworth (grandson of the poet [[William Wordsworth]]) and E.A. Wodehouse (brother of [[P.G. Wodehouse]]) were principals of the college during 1862-74 and 1934-39 respectively.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/pune/A-golden-era-of-history-rusts-at-Deccan-college/articleshow/134146.cms | title=A golden era of history rusts at Deccan college | date=17 August 2003 | newspaper=The Times of India | first=Neil | last=Pate | accessdate=24 September 2018 }}</ref>
===Recent history (1939 till present)=== Deccan College temporarily shut down its teaching activities in 1934 due to lack of funding. It was reopened by order of the [[Bombay High Court]] on 17 August 1939 as a post-graduate and research institute for promoting higher learning and research in [[Indology]] and [[Social Sciences]]. The re-opened institute originally had four teaching and research departments: Archaeology, Linguistics, History, and Sociology-Anthropology.
A Transfer Deed was passed by the Hon’ble Bombay High Court on 16 August 1939 by which the court enjoined the state government to run the institute in perpetuity. As per the Transfer Deed the Deccan College Poona Trust came into existence in which were vested the properties including the land and buildings. In accordance with the provision in the Transfer Deed, the appointments of the Trustees today are made by the State Government.
It was incorporated by the Poona University (now [[University of Pune]]) in 1948, becoming one of its recognized institutions.
The state government was entrusted with preparing the rules for the administration and management of the Deccan College Post-Graduate and Research Institute, which was to cater to studies in post-graduate and research in heritage-related subjects. Thus the Management Council came into existence. In the next half-century the institute, apart from giving instruction to postgraduate students and producing over 500 Ph.D. dissertations, carried out outstanding research in Ancient Indian History, Culture and Archaeology, Linguistics, Medieval and Maratha History, Sociology-Anthropology and Sanskrit Studies.
In recognition of the excellence achieved by the institute in teaching and research, the H.R.D. Ministry, Government of India, awarded it the status of a Deemed University on 5 March 1990. It started functioning as Deemed University from 1 June 1994. Since then the institute has conducted its own courses for M.A. degree and P.G. diploma in Archaeology, M.A. degree in Linguistics, and M.A. degree in Sanskrit and Lexicography, and has enrolled a large number of students for the Ph.D. degree in these disciplines.
Currently, Deccan College has only two teaching and research departments: Archaeology and Linguistics. On the premises are two museums: the Museum of Maratha History, and the Museum of Archaeology. As of 2016, it is currently involved in the ongoing multi-year excavation of the largest [[Indus Valley Civilization]] site of [[Rakhigarhi]] in [[Hisar district]] of [[Haryana]].
==Extra-academic== Deccan College had the oldest boat club in India, called the Poonah Boat Club. The site has since been discontinued and is completely overrun by the slums behind Shadal Baba Dargah.<ref>Illustration 'India: The Poonah Boat Club: Bringing Down the Boats' in ''The Graphic'' (6 October 1877), p. 332.</ref>

A '''diffuser''' is "a device for reducing the velocity and increasing the static pressure of a fluid passing through a system”.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |chapter-url= http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/diffuser.html |contribution=diffuser |title=Merriam–Webster Dictionary |accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> Diffusers are used to slow the fluid's velocity while increasing its static pressure. The fluid's static pressure rise as it passes though a duct is commonly referred to as pressure recovery. In contrast, a [[nozzle]] is often intended to increase the discharge velocity and lower pressure while directing the flow in one particular direction.
Frictional effects during analysis can sometimes be important, but usually they are neglected. Ducts containing fluids flowing at low velocity can usually be analyzed using [[Bernoulli's principle]]. Analyzing ducts flowing at higher velocities with [[mach number]]s in excess of 0.3 usually require [[Compressible flow]] relations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mach Number|url=https://www.grc.nasa.gov/www/k-12/airplane/mach.html|website=NASA|publisher=National Aeronautics and Space Administration|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref>
A typical, subsonic diffuser is a [[Duct (HVAC)|duct]] that increases in size in the direction of flow. As the duct increases in size, fluid velocity decreases, and static pressure rises. Both [[mass flow rate]] and [[Bernoulli's principle]] are responsible for these changes in pressure, and velocity.
==Supersonic Diffusers==
A supersonic diffuser is a duct that decreases in size in the direction of flow. As the duct decreases in size, fluid temperature, pressure, and density increase, while velocity decreases. [[Compressible flow]] is responsible for these changes in pressure, velocity, density, and temperature. [[Shock wave]]s may also play an important role in a supersonic diffuser.
== HVAC == [[Image:Central ventilation tube2.jpg|thumb|250px|A round diffuser in an HVAC system]]
Diffusers are very common in [[HVAC|heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning]] systems.<ref>''Designer's Guide to Ceiling-Based Air Diffusion'', ASHRAE, Inc., Atlanta, GA, USA, 2002</ref> Diffusers are used on both all-air and air-water HVAC systems, as part of [[room air distribution]] subsystems, and serve several purposes:
* To deliver both conditioning and ventilating air * Evenly distribute the flow of air, in the desired directions * To enhance mixing of room air into the primary air being discharged * Often to cause the air jet(s) to attach to a ceiling or other surface, taking advantage of the [[Coanda effect|Coandă effect]] * To create low-velocity air movement in the occupied portion of room * Accomplish the above while producing the minimum amount of [[noise]]
When possible, dampers, extractors, and other flow control devices should not be placed near diffusers' inlets (necks), either not being used at all or being placed far upstream. They have been shown to dramatically increase noise production. For as-cataloged diffuser performance, a straight section of [[duct (HVAC)|duct]] needs serve a diffuser. An elbow, or kinked flex duct, just before a diffuser often leads to poor air distribution and increased noise.
Diffusers can be as a shape of round, rectangular, or can be as linear slot diffusers(LSDs, e.g.: Linear slot diffusers takes the form of one or several long, narrow slots,mostly semi-concealed in a fixed or suspended ceiling.
Occasionally, diffusers are mostly used in reverse fashion, as air inlets or returns. This is especially true for Linear slot diffuser and 'perf' diffusers. But more commonly, [[grille]]s are used as return or exhaust air inlets.
==See also== * [[Bernoulli's principle]] * [[Compressible flow]] * [[Duct (flow)]] * [[Mass flow rate]] * [[Air conditioning]] * [[ASHRAE]] * [[SMACNA]] * [[Air Conditioning Contractors of America|ACCA]] * [[Nozzle]]

[[File:Dry river 2.jpg|thumb|A dried-up river in [[Ehrwald]]]] An '''endangered river''' is one which has the potential to partly or fully dry up, or one that is thought to have [[ecology|ecological]] issues now or in the near future.<ref name="WWF" /> Some such issues are natural while others are the direct result of human development. Organisations including the [[World Wildlife Fund]] (WWF) have published lists of rivers at risk. The WWF's 2007 list featured the [[Danube]], the [[Nile]], and the [[Rio Grande]] amongst others, stating that these "once great rivers" are in danger and "can no longer be assured of reaching the sea unhindered".<ref name="WWF" /> The US [[National Park Service]] reported in 2015 that part of the Rio Grande "often lies dry".<ref name="NPS" /> Dangers may be the result of the natural change of conditions in the local environment but many are due to human development projects such as [[dam]]s and [[irrigation]]. Humans have also caused significant [[water pollution]] which endangers life which relies upon the water source.
==Importance== According to the [[World Resources Institute]] (WRI) [[river basin]]s are "indispensable resources for billions of people, companies, farms, and ecosystems" but many suffer from "water stress". It states that numerous major rivers around the world have become depleted to the point that they can fail to reach their destinations.<ref name="WRI14" /> [[Water scarcity]] is a danger to all the life that depends on the source.
==Dangers to rivers== [[File:Beaver dam in Tierra del Fuego.jpg|thumb|[[Beaver eradication in Tierra del Fuego|Beavers from North America constitute an invasive species]] in [[Tierra del Fuego]].]] [[River]]s face many dangers, both natural and manmade. [[Climate change]] can have a significant impact on rivers, both positive and negative. This could be seen itself as an indirect result of human developments. An area which has a reduction in rainfall or an increase in temperature can make a river fully or partially dry out. This often means that the water can no longer reach its [[river mouth|mouth]].<ref name="WWF" />
The [[flora]] and [[fauna]] of an area can face change and can have a substantial impact on landscape and local ecology.<ref name="WWF" /> [[Invasive species]] can move into an area or be introduced by humans. One particular example of the latter is the case of beavers being introduced into [[Tierra del Fuego]] in 1946. While only 20 animals were transplanted into the area they quickly reproduced with no natural predator to curb numbers. Their effect on the area, through the damaging gnawing of trees and the building of [[beaver dam|their dams]], has been significant enough that humans continue an attempt to undo their mistake with [[Beaver eradication in Tierra del Fuego|a program of beaver eradication]]. The ponds created by the beavers, which now number in the tens of thousands, have greatly contributed to the amount of organic matter retained by the rivers which then causes more problems downstream.<ref name="SA14" />
===Specific human factors=== Human interference in the form of [[river engineering]] can redirect the flow of the water using [[dam]]s or channelisation.<ref name="WWF" /> The increasing demand from [[irrigation|irrigated]] agriculture, continued industrialisation, and residential use heavily impacts upon the health of river systems. This means that many areas face high levels of "baseline water stress".<ref name="WRI14" /> Rivers can be cut off from their [[floodplain]]s and their normal route can be changed or disrupted significantly. If improperly managed this can have a devastating effect on the surrounding area and endanger the plants and animals that depend on them, including humans. [[Water pollution]] is another artificial danger which can be a serious threat to wildlife and human health.<ref name="WWF" /> The [[Colorado River]] runs from the [[Rocky Mountain National Park]] in [[Colorado]] through four other states, parts of [[Mexico]], and then on to the [[Gulf of California]]. Due to the human demands for water very little reaches Mexico and what does is often polluted.<ref name="MNNcol" /> The [[Teesta River]] faces similar issues. The river flows through India and into Bangladesh, but India's water demands led to the part of the river in Bangladesh to dry up in 2018. If the situation continues it could be catastrophic for the local ecosystem.<ref name="DT18" />
[[Image:Big Bend National Park - Rio Grande riverbed with cracked mud.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Rio Grande]] occasionally runs dry in [[Big Bend National Park]].]] The [[Rio Grande Project]] was an irrigation, [[hydroelectricity]], [[flood control]], and [[Interbasin transfer|interbasin water transfer]] project serving the upper [[Rio Grande]] basin in the southwestern United States. It was completed in 1952 and has had a significant impact on the surrounding area. In the past, the river was wide, deep and fast-flowing in its section through Texas, where it forms a large part of the [[Mexico – United States border]]. [[Illegal immigration to the United States|Illegal immigrants]] once had to swim across the river at the border, but with the river so low immigrants need only wade across for most of the year. After leaving [[El Paso, Texas|El Paso]] the Rio Grande often runs dry because so much water has been diverted away for human use.<ref name="NPS" /> Other than extensive diversions, exotic introduced, fast-growing and water-consuming plants, such as [[Eichhornia crassipes|water hyacinth]] and [[hydrilla]], are also leading to reduced flows. The United States government has recently attempted to slow or stop the progress of these weeds by [[Biological pest control|introducing]] insects and fish that feed on the invasive plants.<ref name="bnet" />
==Reports== [[File:Citarum River pollution, 2009.jpg|thumb|Pollution on the [[Citarum River]]]] In 2014 a [[Channel 4]] report suggested that the [[Indonesia]]n [[Citarum River]], forty miles east of [[Jakarta]], may be the most polluted river in the world. Running from [[Wayang-Windu|Mount Wayang]] to the [[Java Sea]], there are over 30 million residents who rely on the river. Rapid [[industrialisation]] has had such a harmful effect that the river's surface cannot be seen for the waste and detritus floating on top of it.<ref name="Teleg14" />
===World Wildlife Fund report=== The WWF published on their website the "10 Rivers most at Risk", a report from March 2007. They based their criteria on major rivers which already suffer or are particularly likely in the future to suffer from six key threats: dams and infrastructure, excessive water extraction, climate change, invasive species, over-fishing, and pollution. They noted that some of the greatest rivers "can no longer be assured of reaching the sea unhindered". The ten rivers which most concerned them are:<ref name="WWF" /> {{columns-list| *[[Salween River]] *[[Río de la Plata|La Plata]] *[[Danube]] *[[Rio Grande]] *[[Ganges]] *[[Murray–Darling basin]] *[[Indus River]] *[[Nile]] *[[Yangtze]] *[[Mekong]] }}
===American Rivers reports=== Each year [[American Rivers]] publishes a list containing ten of "America's Most Endangered Rivers". In 2018 its criteria focused on "threats [to rivers] from the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administration]]" and they selected the [[Sunflower River|Big Sunflower River]] as the one most endangered using their criteria. The river is one of the main [[tributary|tributaries]] of the [[Yazoo River]] in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Mississippi]] but is threatened by the Yazoo Backwater Area Pumping Plant project which they say has the potential to damage 200,000 acres of important [[wetland]].<ref name="AR2018" />
===World Resources Institute project=== The World Resources Institute's Aqueduct project evaluated, mapped, and rated the state of the water supplies for 100 river basins in areas of high population. Their list highlighted the dangers to the [[Qom (River)|Qom River]], [[Yongding River]], [[Brantas River]], and [[Hari (Afghanistan)|Heray Rud River]] amongst others.<ref name="WRI14" />
